title: Supermarkets RUNNING OUT of fruit and vegetables: Lettuce, broccoli and cabbage rationed
text: Supermarkets RUNNING OUT of fruit and vegetables: Lettuce, broccoli and cabbage rationed Supermarkets RUNNING OUT of fruit and vegetables: Lettuce, broccoli and cabbage rationed FOOD shoppers have been banned from buying multiple vegetables from supermarkets which are panicking after bad weather in Europe depleted supplies. PUBLISHED: 00:00, Fri, Feb 3, 2017 | UPDATED: 08:08, Fri, Feb 3, 2017 Getty Britain's vegetable aisles are looking very bare due to the crisis Fresh food staples including lettuce, spinach, broccoli, cabbage and peppers are in high demand, with prices also expected to rise. Morrisons limited the number of lettuces customers can buy in a bid to stop restaurateurs from buying their entire stock as they struggle to source enough vegetables. There are also limits on baby spinach, mixed leaves, rocket, lollo rossa, cauliflower, broccoli, peppers, cucumbers, tomatoes and even lemon and oranges. Related articles Vegetable oil putting MILLIONS at risk of dementia The shortages started with courguettes and aubergines at the end of January, but has now hit scores of other shipped in vegetables. Empty shelves have become commonplace across the UK as growers have been unable to supply supermarkets following an extreme mix of drought followed by flooding and freezing conditions in Spain, while poor conditions have also hit farmers in Italy, Greece and Turkey. Meteorologists have warned if weather does not improve in the coming weeks the problem may continue until April, with customers hit by price rises. Getty It started off with courgettes and has now spread to nearly all popular vegetables Concerned shoppers have been sharing pictures on social media of bare supermarket shelves with the hashtags #lettucecrisis and #courgettecrisis. Many have complained about prices nearly tripling in recent weeks, with an aubergine going from 40p to 70p in some outlets. London retail analyst Rob Gregory posted a photo on Twitter of empty boxes in a Tesco and a sign that read: "Due to continued weather problems in Spain, there is a shortage on Iceberg and other varied lettuce products. "To protect the availability for all customers, we are limiting bulk purchases to three per person." He tweeted: "My local Tesco also affected by the lettuce and salad rationing. Not much there to ration though!" Sarah Morton, from Manchester, tweeted a photo of a Morrisons shelf label stating customers could only buy a maximum of two each. She wrote: "Why? I don't get it @Morrisons #arewerunningout.. #lettuce & #HOWMUCH££" Getty Spain has been hit by droughts then snow Getty Supermarkets have apologised to shoppers but they have little choice in the matter Leeds University production officer Joey O'Hagan tweeted: "Just seen iceberg lettuce for £1.40 in Sainsbury's. A few months back it was 40p." Spain normally supplies half the vegetables on the European market during the winter months. Supermarkets have been forced to look as far afield as the US west coast - more than 5,300 miles from Britain - to meet demand. Coos Hessing, a buyer for Hessing Super Fresh, said the situation for lettuce was "particularly severe". He said: "There have simply been too many cold days, and what's most bizarre about this situation is that it has hit all of south-eastern Europe. "We had seen this before, but you'd need to go back to 15 years ago." Lettuces may also be about two-thirds smaller than usual as buyers look to the USA and Egypt to keep supplies from drying up, Mr Hessing said. Fepex, Spain's largest growers' association, said the extreme conditions amounted to a "force majeure" and the availability of outdoor-grown vegetables will depend on conditions improving in the coming weeks. He said: "It is a situation Fepex envisages remaining until at least early April for leafy vegetables grown in the open air, like lettuces, endives and spinach, and their availability will depend on weather in February and March."
